# Rail Budget

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

**Rail Budget of India** was the Annual Financial Statement of the state-owned
[Indian Railways](/wiki/Indian_Railways "Indian Railways"), which handles
[rail transport in India](/wiki/Rail_transport_in_India "Rail transport in
India"). It was presented every year by the [Minister of
Railways](/wiki/Minister_of_Railways_\(India\) "Minister of Railways
\(India\)"), representing the [Ministry of
Railways](/wiki/Ministry_of_Railways_\(India\) "Ministry of Railways
\(India\)"), in the [Parliament](/wiki/Parliament_of_India "Parliament of
India").

The Railway Budget was presented every year, a few days before the [Union
budget](/wiki/Union_budget_of_India "Union budget of India"), till 2016. [Modi
government](/wiki/Modi_government "Modi government") on 21 September 2016
approved merger of the Rail and [General budgets](/wiki/Union_budget_of_India
"Union budget of India") from next year, ending a 92-year-old practice of a
separate budget for the nation’s largest transporter. Railways Minister
[Suresh Prabhu](/wiki/Suresh_Prabhu "Suresh Prabhu") said that his merger
proposal was in the long term interest of railways as well as the country’s
economy.[1]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Rail_Budget&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

Following the recommendation of the Acworth Committee in 1920-21, headed by
British railway economist [William Acworth](/wiki/William_Mitchell_Acworth
"William Mitchell Acworth")[2] The "Acworth Report" led to reorganisation of
railways, the railway finances were separated from the general government
finances in 1921. After that in 1924 the budget was announced, a practice that
continued till 2016.[3][4][5]

John Mathai presented the first Railway Budget for independent India in
November 1947.

The first live telecast took place on 24 March 1994.

[Lalu Prasad Yadav](/wiki/Lalu_Prasad_Yadav "Lalu Prasad Yadav"), who remained
Railways Minister from 2004 to May 2009, presented the railway budget 6 times
in a row. In 2009, under his tenure a ₹108 billion (US$1.7 billion) budget was
passed.[6]

In the year 2000, [Mamata Banerjee](/wiki/Mamata_Banerjee "Mamata Banerjee")
(later [Chief Minister](/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_West_Bengal "Chief Minister of
West Bengal") of [West Bengal](/wiki/West_Bengal "West Bengal")) became the
first female [Railway Minister](/wiki/Minister_of_Railways_\(India\) "Minister
of Railways \(India\)"). In 2002, she became the first female to present the
Railway budget and is the only woman to do so for two different governing
coalitions ([NDA](/wiki/National_Democratic_Alliance_\(India\) "National
Democratic Alliance \(India\)") and [UPA](/wiki/United_Progressive_Alliance
"United Progressive Alliance")).

In 2014 budget, Railway Minister [D. V. Sadananda
Gowda](/wiki/D._V._Sadananda_Gowda "D. V. Sadananda Gowda") announced the
first [bullet train](/wiki/Shinkansen "Shinkansen") and 9 [High-Speed Rail
routes](/wiki/High-speed_rail_in_India "High-speed rail in India").[7]

The last [Railway Budget](/wiki/Railway_Budget "Railway Budget") [8] was
presented on 25 February 2016 by Mr. [Suresh Prabhu](/wiki/Suresh_Prabhu
"Suresh Prabhu").

Also, according to [Mid-day](/wiki/Mid_Day "Mid Day"), a mumbai centric local
tabloid newspaper, [railway minister](/wiki/Minister_of_Railways_\(India\)
"Minister of Railways \(India\)") [Piyush Goyal](/wiki/Piyush_Goyal "Piyush
Goyal") is planning to introduce 210 air-conditioned suburban local trains and
convert the existing fleet into closed-door, cool trains at the cost of
R16,3809 crore in the Rail Budget of 2018 which is to be presented on 1st
February 2018.[9]
